body.p: Those who support using the sum of undiscounted future cash flows (without allocation of interest costs) as a recognition trigger argue that:

li.p: using a recognition trigger based on undiscounted amounts is consistent with the historical cost framework.
it avoids recognising temporary impairment losses and creating potentially volatile earnings that may mislead users of financial statements.
net selling price and value in use are difficult to substantiate—a price for the disposal of an asset or an appropriate discount rate is difficult to estimate.

it is a higher threshold for recognising impairment losses. It should be relatively easy to conclude that the sum of undiscounted future cash flows will equal or exceed the carrying amount of an asset without incurring the cost of allocating projected cash flows to specific future periods.

body.p: This view was supported by a minority of commentators on E55 Impairment of Assets.
